title: J05-4003

sentences.text: We present a novel method for discovering parallel sentences in comparable , non-parallel corpora .
We train a maximum entropy classifier that , given a pair of sentences , can reliably determine whether or not they are translations of each other .
Using this approach , we extract parallel data from large Chinese , Arabic , and English non-parallel newspaper corpora .
We evaluate the quality of the extracted data by showing that it improves the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system .
We also show that a good-quality MT system can be built from scratch by starting with a very small parallel corpus -LRB- 100,000 words -RRB- and exploiting a large non-parallel corpus .
Thus , our method can be applied with great benefit to language pairs for which only scarce resources are available .

kg2text: Our novel method for discovering parallel sentences in comparable, non-parallel corpora presents a reliable approach to determine whether two given sentences are translations of each other. This method uses the extracted data and can be applied with great benefit to language pairs. A good-quality MT system can be built from scratch by starting with -LRB- 100,000 words -RRB-. We show that this approach has been successfully used to extract parallel data from large Chinese, Arabic, and English non-parallel newspaper corpora. This extracted data is then exploited to build a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system.

In this study, we train a maximum entropy classifier to analyze language pairs such as Chinese, Arabic, and English. The parallel data used for training has its broader term in general data. Furthermore, newspaper corpora are also categorized under the umbrella of data.
